[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the robot is grasping a human wrist. The wrist is dislocated, requiring precise manipulation to set it back in place. The table provides a stable surface. The axes of motion are labeled relative to the grasped wrist.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: the wrist frame is aligned such that X+ corresponds to the right of the wrist, Y+ is coming out of the image and Z+ is pointed up.
The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion upwards in the world. A positive motion is pulling upwards in the world, away from the table. A negative motion is pushing downwards toward the table.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move slightly downwards to accommodate the resetting motion.
The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion to the right in the world. A positive motion is pushing to the right in the world, toward the computer screen and mouse. A negative motion is pushing to the left in the world, towards the robotic arm.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move to the left to allow for resetting.
The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image. A positive motion is pushing into the image. A negative motion is pulling out of the image.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move slightly into the image to help the reset, since dislocation could be oriented along multiple axes.
To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved in a combination of motions that include moving slightly down along the Z-axis, to the left along the X-axis, and slightly into the image along the Y-axis. There may also be minor adjustments in rotation.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: The human wrist is composed of bone, ligament, and muscle. It has moderate stiffness and some degree of compliance due to the soft tissues. The estimated mass of the grasped portion of the arm is approximately 1 kg. The coefficient of friction between the robot gripper and the skin/clothing is estimated to be 0.6. The wrist joint, when dislocated, may have a higher degree of internal static friction than normal due to misalignment of the joint surfaces.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity will act on the arm, but its effect will be minor due to the small mass. The table surface might provide minor frictional resistance. The primary resistance will come from the dislocation itself.
- The relevant object is the human wrist, composed of bone, ligament and muscle. The wrist has some compliance due to soft tissues and the dislocation. This has mass 1 kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.6.
- The surface of interaction is the robot gripper. The table surface is also close by has a static friction coefficient of 0.5 with the object.
- Contact Types: The robot maintains a pinch grasp on the wrist.
- Motion Type: The motion will be a combination of pushing, translation and minor rotations to reset the joint.
- Contact Considerations: The robot must maintain a firm grasp on the wrist to prevent slippage during the resetting motion. Additional force in the Z-axis (downward) and X-axis (left) is needed to overcome the static friction and resistance from the dislocated joint.
- Motion along axes: the robot exerts motion in a “linear,” “rotational,” “some combination” fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes.
- Task duration: The motion should take approximately 2 seconds to complete.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Mass of the wrist: m = 1 kg, coefficient of static friction: μ = 0.6, gravitational acceleration: g = 9.8 m/s^2.
- Relevant equations: F_friction = μ * F_normal.
- Relevant assumptions: The wrist is approximated as a rigid body with a mass of 1 kg. The coefficient of static friction between the gripper and wrist is 0.6.
- Computations: Force to overcome gravity: F_gravity = m * g = 1 kg * 9.8 m/s^2 = 9.8 N. Estimated force required to initiate motion against dislocation is ~5 N. Total force in Z axis to hold the wrist and move downwards is ~9.8 N. With downwards motion of ~5mm, the torque in X and Y axis would be around 1 Nm.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 1 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface: The robot will apply forces along the X, Y, and Z axes and torques about the X and Y axes to reset the dislocated wrist.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon the need to move the wrist slightly to the left and to overcome the static friction/dislocation resistance, the object in the image must exert negative force along the X-axis with magnitude 5 N.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon the need to slightly move the wrist into the image to assist in the reset, the object in the image must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 2 N.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon needing to exert a downward force, the object in the image must exert negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude 10 N.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to apply a slight torque, the object in the image must exert angular clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 1 N-m.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the need to apply a slight torque, the object in the image must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 1 N-m.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon there is no motion about the Z-axis, the object in the image must exert no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0 N-m.
Grasping force:  Based on friction coefficient and the need to apply 10N downward force, grasping force must be sufficient to prevent slippage, estimated thus 20 to 30 N .

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human wrist, mass 1 kg, composed of bone, ligament and muscle, with moderate stiffness and compliance, static friction coefficient of 0.6."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Move the wrist slightly down along the Z-axis, to the left along the X-axis, and slightly into the image along the Y-axis, with minor adjustments in rotation about the X and Y axes."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [-0.005, 0.002, -0.005]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [-5, 2, -10, -1, 1, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 25
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 2
```

[end of motion plan]

Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
